column4: Hi.. 12.04 server. I updated my kernel and was faced with a option screen saying the menu.lst can be modified.  I was offered to leave it alone or choose the package maintainer's version.  Is there anything dangerous about the wrong choice?  Other than booting into the same kernel as before?  For reference: http://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/ubuntu-63/ubuntu-grub-unchanged-734864/  I didn't reboot yet.. thought I'd ask first.
that is grub legacy, i'd use the maintainers one then install Grub2 for an easy life
is there any risk on leaving the original grub alone?  I ask this because this server is 20 miles away.. I took over this role. :)
you could keep it but it is recommended to move to the newer grub
any idea how?  I've looked in the kb settings and it doesn't specify....will i need compiz to do this?
is this what you ultimately want: http://askubuntu.com/questions/105558/how-do-i-disable-the-super-key
sort of.  I did find that page but it didn't specify which super key.
I might just yank the key out :)
each key makes an event ID, the keys are unique
I am aware.. just gotta find where that specific key assignment is being passed from.
run:   xev    and press each key
yes,.. but if I do, then what can I do result?
seems you can use xmodmap to map it
here is one for caps lock, could be useful
yep there are enough clues there.. thanks.
